properties.headline: Flood Advisory issued January 3 at 5:14PM EST until January 3 at 11:30PM EST by NWS Greenville-Spartanburg SC
properties.description:
The National Weather Service in Greenville-Spartanburg has extended
the

* Flood Advisory for...
East central Greenville County in Upstate South Carolina...

* Until 1130 PM EST Friday.

* At 510 PM EST, Doppler radar indicates the earlier heavy rainfall
has ended across central Greenville County; however, an area of 1-3
inches of rainfall occurred between approximately 10:30am and noon,
causing flooding of low-lying areas and several roadways. Excessive
runoff from this rainfall is still working through area streams.
While most small streams have crested and receded, larger streams
including the upper Reedy and Middle Tyger rivers are still out of
banks and are just now cresting.  Therefore, it will take several more
hours for larger streams to crest and fully recede below critical
levels.  Therefore, the Flood Advisory will be extended until these
larger streams fall below Action/Advisory Stage.

* Several reports of flooded roads were received by local media
and law enforcement earlier this afternoon.  These roads included:
Spartanburg St, Hilly St, the Swamp Rabbit Trail at River St,
Lakehurst St, Byrdland Dr, and West Blue Ridge Dr.  While most
floodwaters have receded along smaller streams, residual flooding
of poorly draining areas may continue this evening and areas along
the Reedy River and Swamp Rabbit Trail will remain flooded as well.
It is important to continue to heed all barricades and seek an
alternative route, especially at night.

* The following streamgauges have approached Minor Flood Stage:
Reedy River at Hudson St and Reedy River at Westfield St.

Current Stage: 9.8 feet and cresting.
Forecast: Reedy Creek will recede through this evening and fall
below Action/Advisory Stage before midnight.
Action Stage: 8.0 feet.
Minor Flood Stage: 10.0 feet.
Impacts: At 10.0 feet, Minor Flood Stage. Closure of portions
of the Swamp Rabbit Trail continue, especially near the River St
underpass. Cleveland Park and Lakehurst St are closed due to
backwater flooding along Richland Creek.  Floodwaters are
approaching Hudson St. Backwater effects along Long Branch may
be causing flooding of adjacent low-lying areas, including near
Lily St and Westside Park. Heavy rainfall over Brushy Creek in
W Greenville has forced evacuation of a mobile home on Ross St.

* The following streamgauge has exceeded Action/Advisory Stage:
Brushy Creek at Dry Pocket Rd near Taylors.

Current Stage: 7.61 feet and rising steadily.
Forecast: Brushy Creek will continue to rise to near 8 feet before
cresting by 7pm.
Action Stage: 7.5 feet.
Minor Flood Stage: 13.5 feet.
Impacts: At 8.0 feet, low-lying areas along Brushy Creek from
Devenger Rd to Thornblade Blvd, and Dry Pocket Rd are flooding,
including areas of the Thornblade Golf Club.

* The following streamgauge has exceeded Action/Advisory Stage:
Middle Tyger River at Mt. Lebanon Church Rd. west of Gramling.

Current Stage: 9.16 feet and cresting
Forecast: Middle Tyger River will continue to recede this evening
falling below Action/Advisory Stage later tonight.
Action Stage: 7.5 feet.
Minor Flood Stage: 10.5 feet.
Impacts: At 9.0 feet, Action/Advisory Stage flooding continues.
Resin Creek is flooding near its confluence with the Middle Tyger
River, partially flooding Mt. Lebanon Church Rd. immediately west
of the gauge site with up to 3-6 inches of water.

* Some locations that may continue to experience flooding include...
Greenville Downtown, Greenville Eastside, West Greenville, Greer,
Mauldin, Taylors, Berea, Five Forks, Welcome and Travelers Rest.
properties.instruction:
Turn around, don't drown when encountering flooded roads. Most flood
deaths occur in vehicles.

Be especially cautious at night when it is harder to recognize the
dangers of flooding.
